article.description:
Georgia is beginning to show its
potential, while Alabama continues to fail to live up to its own
expectations.
article.headline: Despite late rally, Tide's free fall from the top continues
article.linkText: Tide hits new low, falls to Georgia in Tuscaloosa
article.story: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. (AP) -- Georgia is beginning to show its potential, while Alabama continues to fail to live up to its own expectations. Jarvis Hayes scored 23 points and the Bulldogs (No. 24 ESPN/USA Today; No. 22 Associated Press) survived a wild comeback attempt to beat Alabama 74-69 Tuesday night, the Crimson Tide's sixth defeat in eight games. ''This is the kind of basketball that I expect our team to play,'' Georgia coach Jim Harrick said. ''It's who we are.'' The Bulldogs (15-7, 7-4 Southeastern Conference) watched a 13-point lead trimmed to four over the final 2:21 before nudging the former No. 1 team a step further from a possible at-large berth for the NCAA Tournament. The Crimson Tide (14-8, 4-7) hit three 3-pointers in the final rally after missing 13 in a row. Mo Williams, who had 15 of his 22 points in the second half despite battling the flu, hit a 3-pointer with 41 seconds left and added a layup 14 seconds later to make it 73-69. ''It was too late,'' the Tide's Kennedy Winston said. ''We put a lot of effort into it, but we just came up a little short tonight.'' The Bulldogs, who had lost six of their first eight road games, missed six of seven free throw attempts in the final 33 seconds, including four in a row by Ezra Williams. Ezra Williams atoned with a big defensive play, stripping the ball from Mo Williams and hitting the second of two foul shots with 16 seconds left. ''He came down the last two possessions before that and went straight past the defense and that kept them in the game,'' said Georgia's Williams, who had 16 points. ''I didn't want him to go to the cup, so I stuck my finger in there and got the steal.'' The Tide missed two desperation 3s as time wound down. Hayes, who played much of the second half with four fouls, was 10-for-17 from the field. Chris Daniels added 11 points for the Bulldogs, who are 5-0 against teams from the SEC West. Erwin Dudley, who fouled out late in the game, had 19 points for the Tide and Winston added 13. Most of Dudley's points came at the free throw line, where he was 7-for-8, or with a couple of defenders draped around him. Harrick said stopping Dudley was the Bulldogs' defensive focal point, but Alabama helped with tentative offense. ''I don't want to give our defense all the credit,'' Harrick said. ''You've got to make shots, and they were hesitant and didn't shoot the ball at all for the first 35 minutes.'' Alabama was 5-for-23 from 3-point range and was outrebounded 41-33. ''We got the thing to four points and had the ball with about 20 seconds to go,'' said Tide coach Mark Gottfried, who was an assistant to Harrick at UCLA. ''Our effort was good, but Georgia's just a very good basketball team. ''They had answers for just about everything we did.'' Alabama, meanwhile, is left with plenty more questions. Namely, can the Tide win enough down the stretch to make the tournament? ''We've got five games left, and I think it's easy for everybody to assume, 'Well, we'll win home games and lose these on the road,''' Gottfried said. ''You can't assume anything. We've got to play, and obviously we've got to play well.'' The Tide, which had seemed to snap out of its offensive funk with 84 points against Auburn, went into a big one before halftime. Alabama made just one field goal over the final 8:30 of the first half and missed its final eight 3-point attempts to fall behind 39-27. ''That stretch at the end of the first half, I think, was the difference in the game,'' Gottfried said. It came on the heels of a brief momentum swing in Alabama's favor. Harrick was charged with a technical foul after Dudley drew a foul. Mo Williams hit the two free throws for the technical and Dudley hit two more to cap a 7-0 run that tied the game at 25-all with 3:40 left. From there, Alabama missed five of six shots, had three turnovers, including a charging violation, and failed to get a final shot off after taking possession with 26 seconds left. ''We have got to regroup,'' Alabama guard Antoine Pettway said. ''It can be done.''
